titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Mary Smyth Hunter Correspondence
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday March 27, 2019 at 03:19

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Autograph manuscript letters and postcards, mostly signed, addressed to Mary Smyth Hunter and to two of her descendants, her daughter Cary Phyllis (Hunter) Williamson, and her grand-daughter Elizabeth Williamson. Major correspondents include Maurice Baring, Max Beerbohm, Gabriel Fauré, Edmund Gosse, Edvard Grieg, George Henschel, Henry James, William James, Claude Monet, George Moore, Auguste Rodin, John Singer Sargent, Henry Tonks, Edith Wharton, and Virginia Woolf. The collection also features approximately 275 pieces of correspondence to Elizabeth Williamson from Mary Smyth Hunter's sister, the composer and suffragist Ethel Smyth.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Joan Winterkorn on the James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection Fund, 2013.

accessrestrict.head: Information About Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Mary Smyth Hunter Correspondence is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Cite As
prefercite.p: Mary Smyth Hunter Correspondence. James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

bioghist.head: Mary Smyth Hunter (1856-1933)
bioghist.p: Mary (Smyth) Hunter (1856-1933), born in India to Major General John Smyth (1815-1894) and Nina (Struth) Smyth, married the wealthy coal-mining heir Charles Edward Hunter in 1875. Mary was known for her lavish hospitality at Hill Hall, their country house near Epping, in Essex county, England, and for her patronage of musicians, writers, and artists.

scopecontent.head: Description of the Papers
scopecontent.p: Autograph manuscript letters and postcards, mostly signed, addressed to Mary Smyth Hunter and to two of her descendants, her daughter Cary Phyllis (Hunter) Williamson, and her grand-daughter Elizabeth Williamson. Major correspondents include Maurice Baring, Max Beerbohm, Gabriel Fauré, Edmund Gosse, Edvard Grieg, George Henschel, Henry James, William James, Claude Monet, George Moore, Auguste Rodin, John Singer Sargent, Henry Tonks, Edith Wharton, and Virginia Woolf. The collection also features approximately 275 pieces of correspondence to Elizabeth Williamson from Mary Smyth Hunter's younger sister, the composer and suffragist Ethel Smyth.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Letters to Mary Smyth Hunter, 1895-1935. II. Letters to Elizabeth Williamson, 1923-1940. III. Letters to Phyllis Williamson, 1898-1936.

controlaccess.subject: Composers -- England -- Correspondence
Country life -- Great Britain
controlaccess.geogname: Great Britain -- Social life and customs -- 20th Century

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I. consists of letters to Mary Smyth Hunter. Larger files can be found for Henry James, Claude Monet, George Moore, John Singer Sargent, and for Mary's younger sister, the composer and suffragist Ethel Smyth. Other correspondents include Max Beerbohm, Gabriel Fauré, Edmund Gosse, Edvard Grieg, George Henschel, William James, Auguste Rodin, and Edith Wharton.

did.unittitle: Louise Margaret, Princess, Duchess of Connaught

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II. consists of letters to Elizabeth Williamson. The series features approximately 275 pieces of correspondence, including both autograph letters and postcards, signed, from Elizabeth's great aunt, the composer and sugffragist Ethel Smyth. There are also letters from Maurice Baring, Ariana Wormeley Curtis, George Moore, Henry Tonks, and Virginia Woolf.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III. consists of letters to Phyllis Williamson. Larger files can be found for George Moore and Henry Tonks. Other correspondents include George Henschel, Joseph M. Hone, and Alfred Sutro.
